data.title: California Digest 1 pm
data.meta_description: Here's a look at how AP's general news coverage is shaping up for select California stories. For up-to-the-minute information on AP's complete coverage of California and the rest of the world, visit  …
data.text:
Here's a look at how AP's general news coverage is shaping up for select California stories. For up-to-the-minute information on AP's complete coverage of California and the rest of the world, visit Coverage Plan at newsroom.ap.org

Questions about coverage plans are welcome and should be directed to the AP-Los Angeles bureau at 213-626-1200, losangeles@ap.org, or to the AP-San Francisco bureau at 415-495-1708, sanfrancisco@ap.org. John Antczak is on the Los Angeles news desk. Olga Rodriguez is on the San Francisco news desk. AP-California news manager Julie Watson can be reached at jwatson@ap.org.

For access to AP Newsroom and other technical issues, contact AP Customer Support at apcustomersupport@ap.org or 877-836-9477.

This information is not for publication or broadcast, and these coverage plans are subject to change. Expected stories may not develop, or late-breaking and more newsworthy events may take precedence. Coverage Plan will keep you up to date. All times are Pacific unless specified otherwise.

TOP STORIES:

OLY—LOS ANGELES 2028-PLANNING

PARIS — From the City of Love to the City of Angels, planning for the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics is well underway and organizers are paying close attention to what’s worked, and what hasn’t, so far in Paris. It will be LA’s third time hosting the Olympics — the last time was 40 years ago — and first time hosting the Paralympic Games. By Noreen Nasir. SENT: 434 words, photos, audio.

CAPITOL RIOT-ARREST

A California woman is charged with taking a cache of weapons, including a sword, a steel whip and a knife into the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6, 2021, attack by a mob of Donald Trump supporters, according to court records unsealed Wednesday. By Michael Kunzelman. SENT: 375 words, photo.

ELECTION 2024-KENNEDY-NEW YORK

ALBANY, N.Y. — Robert F. Kennedy Jr. insisted he plans to return from California to live in New York, as the independent presidential candidate was grilled for a second day Wednesday about his actual residency and whether he should be kept off the Empire State’s ballot in November. By Michael Hill. SENT: 650 words, photos.

HOMELESSNESS FUNDS-AUDIT

California put hundreds of millions of homelessness dollars at risk because of its “disorganized” and “chaotic” anti-fraud policies, according to a critical federal audit. By Marisa Kendall/CalMatters. SENT: 970 words.

DAM REMOVALS-INFRASTRUCTURE SPENDING

BOONE, N.C. — An infusion of hundreds of millions of dollars from the federal infrastructure law is helping expedite efforts to remove dams around the country. Many groups are already using that money to remove mostly small dams from North Carolina to California. By Michael Casey and Erik Verduzco. SENT: 1,240 words, photos, video.

BUSINESS:

DISNEY-RESULTS

The Walt Disney Co. returned to a profitable third quarter as its combined streaming business started making money for the first time and the movie “Inside Out 2” did well in theaters. By Business Writer Michelle Chapman. SENT: 788 words.

LYFT-RESULTS

Lyft shares tumbled to their biggest loss in more than a year on Wednesday after the ride-hailing app reported gross bookings that spooked investors. SENT: 192 words, photo.

ENTERTAINMENT:

COMICS-PEANUTS CORN MAZES

NEW YORK — Visitors to corn mazes across the country are finding a familiar and joyous figure in the winding labyrinth of tall stalks. Snoopy. More than 80 farms in the U.S. and Canada have teamed up with Peanuts Worldwide to create “Peanuts”-themed mazes to celebrate the beloved strip’s 75th birthday this summer and fall. By Mark Kennedy. SENT: 637 words, photos.

SPORTS:

FBN--18-GAME SEASON

SANTA CLARA, Calif. — The 16-game schedule lasted more than four decades in the NFL. Just three years after players and owners agreed to add a 17th game, there is already talk of going to 18 games as the league keeps looking for new revenue sources. By Pro Football Writer Josh Dubow. SENT: 850 words, photos.

FBC—NCAA-MICHIGAN

ANN ARBOR, Mich. — The NCAA announced a four-year show-cause order for former Michigan coach Jim Harbaugh on Wednesday for impermissible contact with recruits and players while access was restricted during the COVID-19 pandemic, effectively banning him from college athletics until August 2028. Harbaugh left his alma mater to coach the Los Angeles Chargers after last season’s national championship. By Sports Writer Larry Lage. SENT: 697 words, photos.

FBN--SEAHAWKS-GRUBB

RENTON, Wash. — One of the great unknowns about the Seattle Seahawks entering this season is whether the offense that Ryan Grubb took all the way to the national championship game a season ago in college will be able to translate to the NFL with the same success. The first glimpse of it comes Saturday when the Seahawks open the preseason against the Chargers. By Tim Booth. UPCOMING: 600 words by 4:30 p.m.

BBA--WHITE SOX-ATHLETICS

OAKLAND, Calif. — Chicago plays Oakland at Oakland Coliseum. By Ben Ross. UPCOMING: 700 words, photos. Started 12:37 p.m.

BBN--PADRES-PIRATES

PITTSBURGH — The Pittsburgh Pirates and San Diego Padres continue a three-game series on Wednesday night at PNC Park. UPCOMING: 600 words, photos. Starts 3:40 p.m.

BBN--GIANTS-NATIONALS

WASHINGTON — San Francisco plays Washington at Nationals Park. By Harvey Valentine. UPCOMING: 600 words, photos. Starts 3:45 p.m.

BBA--ANGELS-YANKEES

NEW YORK — Nestor Cortes starts for the New York Yankees and Carson Fulmer for the Los Angeles Angels. UPCOMING: 650 words, photos. Starts 4:05 p.m.

BBN--PHILLIES-DODGERS

LOS ANGELES — Tyler Phillips starts for the Philadelphia Phillies against Gavin Stone and the Los Angeles Dodgers in the series finale between NL division leaders. By Beth Harris. UPCOMING: 700 words, photos. Starts 7:10 p.m.

LOCALIZATION:

FINANCIAL-MARKETS-LOCALIZE IT: Stocks are bouncing higher on Wall Street as a bit more fear washes out of global markets following their steep slides that began last week. Starting Thursday, investors grew worried about a slowing U.S. economy. They pointed fingers at the Fed for waiting too long to cut rates and sold shares of technology companies that had ridden a frenzy around artificial intelligence to lofty stock market valuations. For individual investors, experts say it’s not time for rash decisions, but a moment to make sure their investments are properly diversified. We provide additional context on financial markets. Find the latest Localize It guides.

US--EDUCATION-HEAD START-LOCALIZE IT: Over the last decade enrollment has taken a steep dive in federal Head Start programs, which have provided early education and other services for families in poverty dating back to the 1960s. In 2013, more than 1.1 million people were served by Head Start (mostly children, but also some pregnant people). By 2022, that number had fallen to around 786,000. That’s according to the Annie E. Casey Foundation, which analyzed federal data. Some have closed after they lost a building lease, faced a rent hike or because interest in the program dropped when free prekindergarten was introduced. But Head Start operators say the decline owes also to a difficult labor market, with employees leaving for the retail and service sectors where they often can earn higher wages. We provide context for the closures and resources for viewing Head Start enrollment trends in your area, along with suggestions for local reporting. Find the latest Localize It guides.

US--CAMPUS PROTESTS-ARRESTS-LOCALIZE IT: More than 3,200 people were arrested on campuses this spring during a wave of pro-Palestinian tent encampments protesting the war in Gaza. Many students have already seen those charges dismissed. But the cases have yet to be resolved for hundreds of people at campuses that saw the highest number of arrests, according to an analysis of data gathered by The Associated Press. In addition to the legal limbo, those students face uncertainty in their academic careers. We list schools with more than 100 arrests, provide a map with arrest numbers around the country and offer reporting suggestions. Find the latest Localize It guides.

US-MED-LISTERIA-DELI-MEATS-LOCALIZE IT: A deadly food poisoning outbreak has led to the recall of more than 7 million pounds of Boar’s Head deli meats made at a plant in Virginia. U.S. health officials are continuing to investigate the outbreak of the bacteria listeria that began in May. Two people have died and nearly three dozen were hospitalized in 13 states. The meat was distributed to stores nationwide, as well as to the Cayman Islands, the Dominican Republic, Mexico and Panama, Agriculture Department officials said. We list the 13 states impacted, link to a list of the recalled items and provide reporting suggestions. Find the latest Localize It guides.

OLY-TEAM USA-LOCALIZE IT: The 2024 Summer Olympicsin Paris run through Aug. 11 with American athletes competing for medals in 45 different sports. The Paralympics run Aug. 28 through Sept. 8 in 22 sports. We provide a list of qualifying athletes on Team USA and their ties across the country and links to coverage plans. Find the latest Localize It guides.

AUDIO:

Tropical Storm Debby swirls over Atlantic, expected to again douse the Carolinas before moving north

Nobel laureate Yunus will head Bangladesh’s interim government after unrest ousted Hasina

US abortion numbers have risen slightly since Roe was overturned, study finds

Wesley Bell defeats ‘Squad’ member Cori Bush. A pro-Israel group spent $8.5 million to help oust her

TOP US/WORLD STORIES:

ELECTION 2024 — Vice President Kamala Harris and Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz are spending their first full day as running mates rallying Democrats across the Midwest. The stops in Wisconsin and Michigan aimed at shoring up support among the younger, diverse, labor-friendly voters who were instrumental in helping President Joe Biden win the 2020 election. But that coalition has shown signs of fraying. By Darlene Superville and Joey Cappelletti. SENT: 1,050 words, photos. Developing from events scheduled to begin after 2:30 p.m.

ELECTION-2024-HARRIS-GETTING-TO-WALZ — Kamala Harris’ whirlwind process to select Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as her running mate can be summed up in a word: weird. Democrats weren’t supposed to have to search for a vice presidential candidate in the first place. But when President Joe Biden ended his campaign and endorsed Harris, it was go time. By Seung Min Kim, Bill Barrow and Zeke Miller. SENT: 2,500 words, photos. An abridged version of 1,000 words is also available.

ABORTION — Abortion was slightly more common across the U.S. in the first three months of this year than it was before the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade and cleared the way for states to implement bans, a report found. A major reason for the increase is that some Democratic-controlled states enacted laws to protect doctors who use telemedicine to see patients in places that have abortion bans. By Geoff Mulvihill and Kimberlee Kruesi. SENT: 1,010 words, photos.

UNITED-STATES-GUANTANAMO-9/11 — Military-run hearings for accused Sept. 11 mastermind Khalid Sheikh Mohammed and two co-defendants at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, are in upheaval following Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin’s decision to throw out a plea agreement. Defense lawyers contend the deals still stand and have suspended participation in the pre-trial hearings while legal challenges to Austin’s action play out. And the judge acknowledges concerns over outside pressure in the case. By Ellen Knickmeyer. SENT: 730 words, photo.

BANGLADESH-PROTESTS — Bangladesh’s incoming interim leader Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus asked his people to stay calm and get ready to rebuild the nation after weeks of violence that left hundreds killed, following an uprising that forced former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina to step down and flee to neighboring India. By Julhas Alam. SENT: 1,120 words, photos, video.

OLY-SIMONE-IN-THE-SPOTLIGHT — Every single thing Simone Biles did at the Paris Olympics, where she won four medals, was studied and scrutinized. Her online feud with a former teammate made headlines, as did her social media post that appeared to take a swipe at presidential candidate Donald Trump. By National Writer Jenna Fryer. SENT: 1,050 words, photos.

AP STORYSHARE:

Looking for more state news and photos? Sign up to participate in AP StoryShare, an online platform where news organizations from a growing list of states share content.

Besides state and regional news, StoryShare offers distinctive reporting around broad topics such as climate, education and Indigenous affairs. Access to StoryShare is free for AP members. For account information, contact Gary Roundtree at groundtree@ap.org or our team at storyshare@ap.org.

------------------------------

If you have photos of regional or statewide interest, please send them to the AP state photo center in New York, 888-273-6867. For access to AP Newsroom and other technical issues, contact AP Customer Support at apcustomersupport@ap.org or 877-836-9477.

------------------------------
